awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Naturalistic effects of landmark scientific reports on public beliefs and attitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
The effects of scientific evidence on the public's beliefs and attitudes are not well understood. In general, prior research suggests that exposure to scientific information is likely to shift people's factual beliefs but may not have corresponding effects on people's opinions or policy preferences. This study considers the landmark reports of the International Panel on Climate Change. IPCC reports attract enormous attention, but little experimental evidence exists about their effects on public opinion. This study evaluates the effects of exposure to the report with the goal of resolving longstanding puzzles about the effect of scientific evidence on beliefs and attitudes regarding polarizing issues and how these effects vary by the quantity of evidence to which people are exposed. The new knowledge will contribute to improving communications regarding climate change.  

This study consists of a multi-wave experiment centered around the release of the March 2023 IPCC report. Some participants receive an incentive to read the IPCC report and news coverage of it in the period after its release, while other participants are encouraged to consume unrelated information. The study also examines exposure to IPCC news and information in anonymized online behavior data provided by a subset of participants. This component of the research links beliefs and attitudes concerning climate change both to the experimental data regarding exposure to the IPCC report and to other online behavior.

por.por_cntn:
This project evaluated the impact of encouraging people to read the 2023 assessment report of the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). Using a multi-wave panel experiment, we measured how an encouragement affected people's beliefs and attitudes related to climate change. Specifically, we measured whether an encouragement to read the report and/or science news coverage of it prompted people to change their factual beliefs about climate change or their attitudes toward policies intended to address climate change. 

Our design had several distinctive elements. First, unlike other work in this area, our study asked participants to consume the report and/or science news coverage of it in real-world media environments. Second, we tested if more frequent encouragement to read about the report would increase its effects. Third, we measure outcomes over multiple survey waves, allowing us to estimate the durability of any estimated effects. Fourth, we used individual-level web browsing data to assess the extent to which participants actually read the report and/or media coverage of it. Finally, we collected behavioral data concerning participants' willingness to bear costs related to climate change. 

Our findings are as follows. First, we were successful in encouraging exposure to the IPCC report and coverage of it. Web browsing data indicates that approximately half of all participants who received an encouragement to read the report and/or science news coverage of it did so. These findings do not vary based on how many times participants received an encouragement. Our results further show that participants who received an encouragement to read the IPCC report and/or science news coverage of it expressed more accurate beliefs about the science of climate change. The encouragement also led participants to change their views about what the government should do about climate change and the threat posed by climate change. Notably, these effects were similar among people from different parties and those with different prior climate change beliefs and persisted to the end of the study, which concluded two to four weeks after the release of the IPCC report. However, the encouragement did not change respondents' willingness to bear costs related to climate change. 

These findings have important implications for how we communicate about climate change. Previous research has shown that exposure to factual information can improve belief accuracy but rarely changes attitudes. In contrast, encouraging people to read the IPCC report and/or science news coverage of it changes the accuracy of people's beliefs as well as their attitudes toward the issue. Rather than resisting unwelcome information, people across the political spectrum changed their beliefs and attitudes in the direction implied by the information. However, encouraging people to learn more about the IPCC report did not cause corresponding changes in individual behavior. This insight could inform strategies for public engagement on climate issues. Future research should explore ways to bridge the gap between attitude change and behavioral change in response to climate information.
